title: House of Beaumont
text:
The <a href="Normans">Norman</a> family of Beaumont was one of the great baronial <a href="Anglo-Normans">Anglo-Norman</a> families, who became rooted in England after the <a href="Norman%20conquest%20of%20England">Norman Conquest</a>.
History.
<a href="Roger%20de%20Beaumont">Roger de Beaumont</a>, Lord (seigneur) of <a href="Pont-Audemer">Pont-Audemer</a>, of <a href="Beaumont-le-Roger">Beaumont-le-Roger</a>, of <a href="Brionne">Brionne</a> and of <a href="Vatteville">Vatteville</a>, was too old to fight at the <a href="battle%20of%20Hastings">battle of Hastings</a> and stayed in <a href="Normandy">Normandy</a> to govern and protect it while William was away on the invasion. As a reward, he received lands in <a href="Leicestershire">Leicestershire</a>. His son <a href="Robert%20de%20Beaumont%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Leicester">Robert de Beaumont</a>, <a href="counts%20of%20Meulan">comte de Meulan</a>, who commanded the Norman right wing at Hastings, became the first <a href="Earl%20of%20Leicester">Earl of Leicester</a>. His brother <a href="Henry%20de%20Beaumont%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Warwick">Henri de Beaumont</a> was created <a href="Earl%20of%20Warwick">Earl of Warwick</a>.
During <a href="Stephen%20of%20England">Stephen</a>'s reign, the twins <a href="Waleran%20de%20Beaumont%2C%201st%20Earl%20of%20Worcester">Galéran</a> and <a href="Robert%20de%20Beaumont%2C%202nd%20Earl%20of%20Leicester">Robert</a> were powerful allies to the king, and as a reward Galéran (already <a href="comte%20de%20Meulan">comte de Meulan</a>) was made <a href="Earl%20of%20Worcester">Earl of Worcester</a>.
Counsel from the Beaumonts was important to the <a href="Duke%20of%20Normandy">Dukes of Normandy</a>, then by the kings of England.

French branch:<br>
The French Vicomtes de Beaumont au Maine date from approximately 930 AD and contrary to many false assumptions never had, and do not have, any connection with the Norman Beaumonts descended from Roger de Beaumont. The French family take their name from the village of <a href="Beaumont-sur-Sarthe">Beaumont-sur-Sarthe</a> (formerly Beaumont le Vicomte) which is 30 km north of <a href="Le%20Mans">Le Mans</a>. (<a href="Beaumont-le-Roger">Beaumont-le-Roger</a> is about 125 km away, in the vicinity of <a href="Rouen">Rouen</a>). The French family came to England in the late 14th century (see <a href="Isabella%20de%20Vesci">Isabella de Vesci</a>) and modern Beaumonts are descended from her brother <a href="Henry%20de%20Beaumont">Henry de Beaumont</a> who was the first of the English barony and later Viscounts.
They are not a branch of the Norman family - rather they fought against the Normans on behalf of the French (see Hubert de Beaumont).
Armorial.
The Beaumont family was founded before <a href="heraldry">heraldry</a> (c. 1160). So, different branches of the family adopted different arms.
